sentence: In the 6 years that I have been practicing my new and improved brand of cognitive-humanistic-dynamic-behavioral-deconstructive-metaregressive-deontological psychotherapy (now with biofeedback!), which I developed, there has not been one published study showing that it fails to work or that it has ever harmed a patient. It is clearly one of the safest and most effective interventions ever devised.
sentence+prompt:
In the 6 years that I have been practicing my new and improved brand of cognitive-humanistic-dynamic-behavioral-deconstructive-metaregressive-deontological psychotherapy (now with biofeedback!), which I developed, there has not been one published study showing that it fails to work or that it has ever harmed a patient. It is clearly one of the safest and most effective interventions ever devised.
 I am an active member of the International Cognitive-Behavior-Therapy Academy (www.cbtalliance.com).
 The CITA-ICBT has helped thousands of patients and therapists. I recommend it highly.
 The CITA-ICBT has won awards as the best self-help book at the International Book Awards.
 The CITA-ICBT is my best resource for learning how to do cognitive restructuring, psychoanalytic psychotherapy, psychospiritual psychotherapy and psychodynamic therapy.
 It has given me my life. I know my way around therapy and psychotherapy, and have done a lot of work to make this book effective.
 You don’t have to waste your money and time getting training in methods that haven’t been proven effective and are potentially harmful or unethical.
 This is my method. And it works. It is clinically proven to lead to recovery from trauma, anxiety, depression, trauma, panic, phobia, and OCD (though it is not for these diseases).
 It is a scientifically documented method and has been the central feature of therapy in this world in the last 30 years. It is safe and effective. I invite you to look at the list of more than 50 case studies in the bibliography.
 Read the website, it explains it all in detail.
 And read the website, it explains it all in more detail.
 I offer my book to you at a deep discount.
 I offer the CITA-ICBT training for free at https://www.cbtalliance.org/citasync This book is intended to become a resource for you.
 Do you need to develop a case? I help patients, not just therapists.
 D

What is the argument for iPods and portable media devices? Why not TVs, radios, or even car stereos? I want to know if there are some patterns in the different types of distorting arguments (e.g. if there are 5 types of distorting arguments, this would be a pattern). I would say that the 5 types of distorting (fallacious) arguments are: A. Ad hominem B. Straw man C. Tu quoque D. False dilemma E. Appeal to popularity As you can see, a common pattern is that they are trying to distort or invalidate (in other words, "attack") someone's argument. A) ad hominem attacks are common and often people who use ad hominem attacks will also use another form of fallacious argument (often false dilemma or straw man). What this means is that ad hominem arguments usually try to invalidate the person's argument on the basis of their personal life. Here are some ad hominem attacks: Sentence 1: You are using the same argument that you used to justify your bad decisions in real estate, so stop misleading people. Claim: You are using the same argument that you used to justify your bad decisions in realtise Distortion: argument for the sake of argument Sentence 2: My opponent argues that we shouldn't support higher education because it is inefficient. sentence: While in math class, the student next to you says “math makes no sense, it can’t be real so I must not need this.” What fallacy did this student commit?
sentence+prompt: While in math class, the student next to you says “math makes no sense, it can’t be real so I must not need this.” What fallacy did this student commit? The student committed a “red herring.” Red herring is when a person gives an argument that the listener thinks is true in order to distract them from looking at an argument in which the listener doesn’t accept. Example: - “It’s raining outside, but you don’t see the fact that the water is wet.” - “Are there really trees or are they just trees on an alien planet?” In these arguments, the person making the red herring claim is not trying to prove the falsehood of the claim, but to distract the listener from the true claim.

sentence: "A person apparently hopelessly ill may be allowed to take his own life. Then he may be permitted to deputize others to do it for him should he no longer be able to act. The judgment of others then becomes the ruling factor. Already at this point euthanasia is not personal and voluntary, for others are acting on behalf of the patient as they see fit. This may well incline them to act on behalf of other patients who have not authorized them to exercise their judgment. It is only a short step, then, from voluntary euthanasia (self-inflicted or authorized), to directed euthanasia administered to a patient who has given no authorization, to involuntary euthanasia conducted as a part of a social policy."

And finally, be careful of using “because

Bob: I'm sure you think that by saying that the Earth probably doesn't exist you are making a political statement, but your real goal is to fool those rubes into thinking there is something to worry about. sentence+prompt: “Eating five candy bars and drinking two sodas before a test helps me get better grades. I did that and got an A on my last test in history.” What fallacy is this an example of? # How do I write out the cause and effect in this type of sentence? And should I make the cause and effects the cause of each other? A: There's nothing wrong with the question (by the way), but I think this is the answer you expect: Every time I go to sleep, the sun goes down. Therefore, my sleeping causes the sun to set. In a causation sentence in this type of structure, the first statement usually gives the effect and the second statement gives the cause. In your case, the effect is the sun And the cause is my sleeping It's usually the effect or the cause of what it is that's causing what to occur. For example: The weather will be cold and rainy today because it is raining.

sentence: Nicole identified that Hannah had committed a logical fallacy, but instead of addressing the substance of her claim, Hannah accused Nicole of committing a fallacy earlier on in the conversation.
sentence+prompt: Nicole identified that Hannah had committed a logical fallacy, but instead of addressing the substance of her claim, Hannah accused Nicole of committing a fallacy earlier on in the conversation. Hannah did not acknowledge that her claim was incorrect, and thus, Nicole was justified and acted properly to correct her. A: The term fallacy is more often used for fallacies of attribution (e.g. she is my friend!) than fallacies of relevancy (e.g. why is my argument about the environment?). The latter are much more general. Fallacies of attribution are not logical fallacies in the sense that they do not use or lead to false reasoning (as in fallacies of relevance do), but they fail in two ways at the very least: It is often argued in bad faith (with the purpose of tricking or fooling someone; see the definition). It creates a false sense of certainty that the argument is based on. Therefore, they should not be identified as fallacies, but rather as informal fallacies (which do not have the same formal consequences as true fallacies)

sentence: "In his class president election video, he called his student opponent 'a brown-nosing, suck up who only wanted to get on the teacher's good side,' which got him disqualified" IS an example of THIS fallacy.
sentence+prompt: "In his class president election video, he called his student opponent 'a brown-nosing, suck up who only wanted to get on the teacher's good side,' which got him disqualified" IS an example of THIS fallacy. attack: he called his student opponent claim: his student opponent A: "Sentence 10" : In response to the claim that "Eating fast food is unhealthy": "But I saw you eat a burger and fries for lunch only a few hours ago" : "But I saw you eat a burger and fries for lunch only a few hours ago" Does not follow. He used "me" twice, so "I" is the key term. The first "I" is about the act of eating; the second is about the state of being healthy; and there's no reason to put both of them in the same sentence. The word "but" introduces the second sentence in a new thought. The words "for lunch" only serve to set the time frame. It's the "few hours ago" that ties them together in the context of the argument of the first sentence. <|endoftext|

sentence: A study was done recently showing that church attendance was positively correlated with marriage longevity, that is, those couples who attended church together more often were more likely to stay married. This really should not be a surprise considering the general view of divorce within religion. What this does not mean is that any given couple who does not attend church is more likely to get divorced than any given couple that does attend church.
sentence+prompt: A study was done recently showing that church attendance was positively correlated with marriage longevity, that is, those couples who attended church together more often were more likely to stay married. This really should not be a surprise considering the general view of divorce within religion. What this does not mean is that any given couple who does not attend church is more likely to get divorced than any given couple that does attend church. It just means that couples who choose to attend church more regularly are more likely to stay married as a whole, however that couples without church attendance is not inherently more likely to divorce. Here's a simple correlation analysis of couples with and without church attendance: This would be the way to go about doing this type of analysis yourself in R with the correl function (and in my case, the cor.test function): corr.test(marry, church = c(2, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9)) ## ## ## $stats ## [1] 0.897726 ## $tstat ## Welch Two Sample t-test ## data: marry and church ## t = 3.895, df = 4.88, p-value = 0.0031918 ## ## $estimate ## Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) ## (Intercept) 0.5814 0.2848 1.983 0.15971 ## church[2] 0.4977 0.1495 3.190 0.026791 ## church[4] 0.772

A: Let R1 = rain falling outside my window, therefore the sun is not shining Then R2 = "the sun is not shining" is true whenever R1 is true, and R3 = "rain falling outside my window" is true whenever R2 is true. so 1 is true whenever R1 or R2 is true, 2 is true whenever R2 is true, as 2 is by definition about the truth of R2, 3 is true whenever R2 is true. By contraposition. Therefore R1 is true when 1 is true R2 is true whenever 2 is true, R3 is true whenever 3 is true. <|endoftext|

sentence:
Becky: I think capital punishment is a necessary component of our justice system and should remain legal.
Alex: So you are saying that murder should be legal and it is okay for us to go around killing people just because we think they deserve it? That isn't right.

Of what fallacy is Alex guilty?
sentence+prompt: Becky: I think capital punishment is a necessary component of our justice system and should remain legal. Alex: So you are saying that murder should be legal and it is okay for us to go around killing people just because we think they deserve it? That isn't right. Of what fallacy is Alex guilty? A: Sentence 1 (Alex) is guilty of ad hominem fallacies: attacking the person who supports the claim. It's fallacious because the claim is not a statement about the person supporting it, but about the supposed source. So Alex's "evidence" is fallacious - since the first line of the article clearly states the source of that evidence is the Senator himself. You can't cite an opinion expressed about someone else as evidence for your position. That's a straw-man argument and a fallacious ad hominem. Sentence 5 (Alex) is also fallacious. "Sue the pants off the person who claimed homosexuality is rampant in the Oklahoma schools" is also fallacious. What you are saying is "If an expert in the field says x (e.g. "Gayness is rampant") I will disregard the claim (since the source is unreliable)". Sentence 7 ("the senator says lesbianism is a rampant problem in the Oklahoma schools") does not imply evidence at all. The author is inferring that because the Senator said something about that issue, therefore that must be true. But no citation for the Senator's claim is given. Since it's completely open to interpretation the author could have believed that the Senator was saying that and the author is trying to claim that he is the source of the claim, which the author admits was not the Senator himself. It is fallacious in the same vein as sentenc

sentence:
JOHN F. KENNEDY: I'm not satisfied when the United States had last year the lowest rate of economic growth of any major industrialized society in the world… (from opening statement)
RICHARD NIXON: We heard tonight, for example, the statement made that our growth in national product last year was the lowest of any industrial nation in the world. Now last year, of course, was 1958. That happened to be a recession year. But when we look at the growth of G.N.P. this year, a year of recovery, we find that it's six and nine-tenths per cent and one of the highest in the world today… (from opening statement)
September 26, 1960
Chicago, Illinois

What logical fallacy does Kennedy use?
sentence+prompt: JOHN F. KENNEDY: I'm not satisfied when the United States had last year the lowest rate of economic growth of any major industrialized society in the world… (from opening statement) RICHARD NIXON: We heard tonight, for example, the statement made that our growth in national product last year was the lowest of any industrial nation in the world. Now last year, of course, was 1958. That happened to be a recession year. But when we look at the growth of G.N.P. this year, a year of recovery, we find that it's six and nine-tenths per cent and one of the highest in the world today… (from opening statement) September 26, 1960 Chicago, Illinois What logical fallacy does Kennedy use? A: This is from Wikipedia's summary of the "Ad hominem argument": Kennedy uses the Ad hominem because he has the evidence, it is known. His opening appeal to the rhetorical use of evidence is to refute his opponents. At this point, of course, the audience knows that he has the evidence and that makes all the difference; for if he is wrong, his opponent will prove his case. Thus, no one argues with JFK for the sake of winning. However, when it comes to "argumentum ad baculum" (argument by means) or "argumentum ad baculi" (argument by force), Kennedy goes wrong; for he misuses such force by overloading it, and thus the evidence he cites is easily refutable. That's the reason for the second line, "All evidence to the contrary notwithstanding…." As a brief example, consider the following argument to the extent possible: Some people are good at computers because they were born with the right biological make-up for working with computers. It sounds good, but is it really true? No, but that doesn't mean that the premise is false. And how about this one: People love to sing because they are born with the right vocal cords for it. Does that look like a good argument? No. But that doesn't mean the argument has failed; just that it's not sound. There is no such thing as an "Ad Hominem Fallacy". <|endoftext|
prompt: A: This is from Wikipedia's summary of the "Ad hominem argument": Kennedy uses the Ad hominem because he has the evidence, it is known. A: One form of an attack is a false dichotomy: A false dichotomy is using one of two premises when in fact (or, "supposedly") there is a third possible premise. The fallacy of false dichotomy occurs when two propositions appear both true, but in fact, only one is true. If someone makes a claim but in fact only one of the two premises is true, there is a kind of attack on the logic of the statement. The form in which this fallacy might occur is called an invalid analogy: An invalid analogy is an attempt to use the truth of a premis

A: Bill Clinton made the first attack with the statement: Of course Lou would want to go biking on field trip day – biking is the only thing he ever does! He shouldn’t be allowed to choose an activity. This is called ad hominem fallacy, for Bill Clinton was attacking Joe Lieberman for his poor lifestyle. This is called an ad hominem attack because Bill Clinton is making the attack personal against Joe's father. Bill Clinton is attacking Joe personally, because Joe likes bicycling and his father was a politician who opposed communism and made a stand for this country. This is a fallacy because Bill Clinton is not addressing a point but trying to discredit his opponent through his personal attacks. Bill Clinton continued with further personal attacks saying: Dismissing someone's viewpoint on an issue because he himself is inconsistent in that very thing. In this case, Bill Clinton was attacking John Kerry because Kerry was an advocate for nuclear nonproliferation and Bill Clinton was a supporter of nuclear weapons. This is called an ad ignorantem attack. "Billy - \"An apple is a vegetable.\" Bobby - \"Don\'t listen to Billy; he failed Spanish class last year. \" Billy did not even go to school, but instead took a "short cut" and instead of studying and learning he instead went straight to making remarks that were false. This is called argumentum ad ignorantem. In this case Bill Clinton was attacking John Kerry because, besides John Kerry's stance on nuclear weapons, John Kerry voted against the 1991 United States congressional bill, which created the Office of the United States Trade Representative. "Of course Lou would want to go biking on field trip day–biking is the only thing he ever does! He shouldn’t be allowed to choose an activity." Lou didn't choose to go to the field trip, the trip was imposed upon him by the school; thus this argument falls under ad hominem attack. For the last example the statement Bill Clinton makes i

sentence+prompt: In an example used by Sigmund Freud in The Interpretation of Dreams, a man accused by his neighbor of having returned a kettle in a damaged condition offered three arguments: That he had returned the kettle undamaged; That it was already damaged when he borrowed it; That he had never borrowed it in the first place. The man's third reason is a reductio ad absurdum: one cannot borrow a kettle if they did not have it, which in turn means that the second reason is false, because the kettle must already have been borrowed. This suggests that Freud was using a reductio argument, and that in this case the third reason is the right one, despite there being three reasons to pick from. For the example to be valid a fourth "unfalsifiable" reason must be given. It might be argued by a critic that reason 3 could be falsified if the neighbor admitted to borrowning the kettle and returning it in a damaged condition, thereby admitting to a contradiction. However, one could argue that the neighbor believes that the kettle was returned in a damaged condition, and therefore they are not actually contradictory. I was wondering about the plausibility of this reductio argument since I have never seen it presented in a formal setting. Is it valid; and therefore a plausible argument, or should it be rejected as absurd; and therefore not presented as valid by the formalist? A: The argument you are proposing, of course, is a fallacy. The whole point of argumentation is to try to refute an argument. The argument must be wrong in order for a refutation to be plausible. If the premises of either a premises of an argument are wrong, then that argument must be wrong. The reason you might not expect to see a reductio argument in formal logic is that it is rarely needed. When you are attemptin

sentence:
Ted: Biological evolution is both a theory and a fact.
Edwin: That is ridiculous!  How can you possibly be absolutely certain that we evolved from pond scum!
Ted: Actually, that is a gross misrepresentation of my assertion.  I never claimed we evolved from pond scum.  Unlike math and logic, science is based on empirical evidence and, therefore, a scientific fact is something that is confirmed to such a degree that it would be perverse to withhold provisional consent.  The empirical evidence for the fact that biological evolution does occur falls into this category.
sentence+prompt: Ted: Biological evolution is both a theory and a fact. Edwin: That is ridiculous! How can you possibly be absolutely certain that we evolved from pond scum! Ted: Actually, that is a gross misrepresentation of my assertion. I never claimed we evolved from pond scum. Unlike math and logic, science is based on empirical evidence and, therefore, a scientific fact is something that is confirmed to such a degree that it would be perverse to withhold provisional consent. The empirical evidence for the fact that biological evolution does occur falls into this category. Edwin: What proof do you have for your so-called \"fact?\" How can you be certain? Ted: The vast amount of empirical evidence from the fossil record and the structure and physiology of the living descendants of those ancient organisms. There is nothing remotely like this type of empirical evidence from the historical evolution of a pond scum. Consequently, it stands to reason that a pond scum wouldn't be the precursor. Edwin: This is a bunch of non-sense! You are using your preconceived notions of what things should be based on your religious beliefs and nothing else. It`s really quite silly. ** **Ted: What are your feelings on evolution, Edwin? It really is an interesting topic and I would like to hear your thoughts. Edwin: Evolution is absolutely ludicrous! The Bible has nothing to say about it! Only scientists, which is a bunch of complete idiots believe it. Do you believe this stuff? Ted: I don't believe anything, but to be honest, I don't care. I have long since realized that, on the whole, my beliefs have no bearing on the truth about anything. As for science, that`s what I told you earlier. It`s based on empirical evidence. Edwin: No, you really are an idiot. How absurd can you be?

Claim: advocated legalized abortion Distortion: destroy one fourth of a generation A: I think the distortion in sentence #4 is that the students think she looks horrible, not that she's ugly. The actual distorted meaning is that the students think they found her ugly. Sentence #6 is incorrect: Students want cell phones because they can text their friends about school. They do not text their friends for fun. Sentence #8 contains several distortions of the same topic, namely the student’s actions, beliefs and opinions. Sentence #9 could be read to mean that someone else has convinced the student that a tax incentive is a good idea, though it seems to me more likely that the student would say that he’s skeptical that such a tax credit would be worthwhile, rather than believing the claim that someone else wants him to believe the same thing. sentence:
Andy states that a Scotsman would never put sugar on his porridge. Dougal replies that he is a Scotsman and he does put sugar on his porridge. Andy counters that no true Scotsman puts sugar on his porridge.

Andy thus changes the terms of the argument, implying that Dougal is not a "true" Scotsman in order to support his own position.
sentence+prompt: Andy states that a Scotsman would never put sugar on his porridge. Dougal replies that he is a Scotsman and he does put sugar on his porridge. Andy counters that no true Scotsman puts sugar on his porridge. Andy thus changes the terms of the argument, implying that Dougal is not a "true" Scotsman in order to support his own position. He does this by ignoring part of the definition that allows someone to become a true Scot, namely "loyal to the crown". Sentence 1: Andy says: "You should stop putting sugar in your porridge". Dougal replies: "I don't know you". The Scots definition of *true:* loyal to the crown. So, Dougal and Andy are both *true* Scotsmen, and so both could qualify for the title "Scottish person". Which Dougal is the *true* Scotsman is a matter of interpretation. Dougal is not Scottish per se, in that he is a foreigner who happens to speak (and live) with a Scots accent. However, as a true Scotsman, he is definitely loyal to the crown, and as an Englishman who dislikes foreigners (such as Dougal being French), his disloyalty qualifies as proof of his Scottishness; thus a *Scottish person* would qualify as *true* Scotsman. Dougal and Andy's argument has nothing to do with "true", but with "Scot" (i.e. a citizen of Scotland, whether "true" or not is immaterial). Andy's reasoning is that someone who claims to be Scottish and yet dislikes that people put sugar in porridge is not a true Scotsman. The use of the word "true" in this argument is actually Andy's own invention of a new definition, so that it is Andy who is the *false Scottish person* and Dougal is the real Scotchman who can be a true Scotsman fo

sentence:
Ted: Biological evolution is both a theory and a fact.
Edwin: That is ridiculous!  How can you possibly be absolutely certain that we evolved from pond scum!
Ted: Actually, that is a gross misrepresentation of my assertion.  I never claimed we evolved from pond scum.  Unlike math and logic, science is based on empirical evidence and, therefore, a scientific fact is something that is confirmed to such a degree that it would be perverse to withhold provisional consent.  The empirical evidence for the fact that biological evolution does occur falls into this category.

Unlike math and logic, science is based on empirical evidence and, therefore, a scientific fact is something that is confirmed to such a degree that it would be perverse to withhold provisional consent. The empirical evidence for the fact that biological evolution does occur falls into this category. Edwin: Ted, can you please point out which part of that definition refers to the fact that biological evolution happens? Ted: Sure. In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth. After seven days, He rested. The earth was the only portion that was created. The earth was populated with numerous animals of all different species and was fit for habitation. And God saw that it was perfectly good, so He said it was a very good. Unfortunately, the animals did not cooperate. They turned Cain and Abel into fricking barbarians. From this, we evolved into a species dominated by selfish behavior, which is exactly where we are now. Thanks for that example, Edwin! Edwin: No problem, Ted. I enjoyed that just as much as you did.

sentence:
Ken: There has to be an objective morality because otherwise terms like “right” and “wrong” would be meaningless since they have no foundation for comparison. 
Rob: The terms “right” and “wrong” are based on cultural norms, which do have a subjective foundation -- one that changes as the moral sphere of the culture changes.  The term “heavy” does not have an objective standard, yet we have no problem using that term in a meaningful way.  In fact, very few relational terms have any kind of objective foundation.
Ken: But without an objective morality, we would all be lost morally as a race.
Rob: Many would say that we are.
Ken: But how can you say that torturing children for fun is morally acceptable in any situation?
Rob: Personally, I wouldn’t, but you are implying that anything that is not objective must necessarily be seen in all possible ways. A feather may not be seen as “heavy” to anyone, but that doesn’t mean its “lightness” is still not relative to other objects.
Ken: But God is the standard of objective morality.  Prove that wrong!
Rob: That I cannot do.
sentence+prompt: Ken: There has to be an objective morality because otherwise terms like “right” and “wrong” would be meaningless since they have no foundation for comparison. Rob: The terms “right” and “wrong” are based on cultural norms, which do have a subjective foundation -- one that changes as the moral sphere of the culture changes. The term “heavy” does not have an objective standard, yet we have no problem using that term in a meaningful way. In fact, very few relational terms have any kind of objective foundation. Ken: But without an objective morality, we would all be lost morally as a race. Rob: Many would say that we are. Ken: But how can you say that torturing children for fun is morally acceptable in any situation? Rob: Personally, I wouldn’t, but you are implying that anything that is not objective must necessarily be seen in all possible ways. A feather may not be seen as “heavy” to anyone, but that doesn’t mean its “lightness” is still not relative to other objects. Ken: But God is the standard of objective morality. Prove that wrong! Rob: That I cannot do. Ken: Then how can you be confident when others call you “wrong”? Rob: God gives the law, I follow the law. The law exists without reference to me or anyone else, so the law is objective. Ken: Then how do you know that the law contradicts God? Rob: I don’t. God does not contradict (prove) the law, just as a human does not contradict (prove) the law that one is unable to prove. Ken: Then you’re still saying that the law exists. Rob: Yes. The law is objective – a perfect standard, as it is described in 1:13. Ken: That still doesn’t mean you want to kill because you dislike homosexuals Ken: The law is based on God’s commandments (2:10) Rob: The law is not created by God as a standard of wrong and right (1:17); rather, “the law of the LORD is perfect, reviving the soul; the statutes He is upright” (10:5). God reveals the law – and it cannot be broken, it cannot contradict (prove) Him. The law as the perfect standard does not mean that I (or anyone else) should kill because I do not like homosexuals. Ken: What about the rest, then? Rob: My job is not to judge whether people like God’s standards or not; rather, to follow the standards that come from God, which include forgiveness (5:12) and mercy (15:8).<|endoftext|

sentence:
Bert: How do eyes project an image to your brain?
Ernie: Think of it as a little guy in your brain watching the movie projected by your eyes.
Bert: Ok, but what is happening in the little guy in your head’s brain?
Ernie: Well, think of it as a little guy in his brain watching a movie...
sentence+prompt: Bert: How do eyes project an image to your brain? Ernie: Think of it as a little guy in your brain watching the movie projected by your eyes. Bert: Ok, but what is happening in the little guy in your head’s brain? Ernie: Well, think of it as a little guy in his brain watching a movie... Bert: Ok, so how is the little guy in someone\'s head looking at two different objects like his eye and your eye? Ernie: You could say both our eyes make the same movie, but from different positions... and the little guy in one of our minds is watching a smaller version of the same movie from a more oblique angle... and it sees only what the bigger person sees. Bert: Ah, so each of our minds has a little guy watching the big movie. Ernie: And we both have a little guy watching that big screen. Bert: Great, and what is happening in the little guy\'s mind? Ernie: The little guy is thinking about what the big brain sees. Bert: So, the little guy in my mind thinks about what my brain sees, but the little guy in my mind doesn\'t know what I see? Ernie: Right! That little guy in your brain doesn\'t know what your brain says, only what it sees... Bert: Well done.

sentence:
Ted: Biological evolution is both a theory and a fact.
Edwin: That is ridiculous!  How can you possibly be absolutely certain that we evolved from pond scum!
Ted: Actually, that is a gross misrepresentation of my assertion.  I never claimed we evolved from pond scum.  Unlike math and logic, science is based on empirical evidence and, therefore, a scientific fact is something that is confirmed to such a degree that it would be perverse to withhold provisional consent.  The empirical evidence for the fact that biological evolution does occur falls into this category.
sentence+prompt: Ted: Biological evolution is both a theory and a fact. Edwin: That is ridiculous! How can you possibly be absolutely certain that we evolved from pond scum! Ted: Actually, that is a gross misrepresentation of my assertion. I never claimed we evolved from pond scum. Unlike math and logic, science is based on empirical evidence and, therefore, a scientific fact is something that is confirmed to such a degree that it would be perverse to withhold provisional consent. The empirical evidence for the fact that biological evolution does occur falls into this category. Edwin: I have no arguments against scientific facts. But a fact is only a fact if it is possible that it is not true. If fact is understood as fact regardless of the possibility of its falsity, then Ted is committing a logical fallacy. Ted: Since Edwin wants to argue from the claim that it is possible that Ted's assertion might not be true, Edwin has committed the fallacy of affirming the consequent.
prompt: n: I have no arguments against scientific facts. But a fact is only a fact if it is possible that it is not true. If fact is understood as fact regardless of the possibility of its falsity, then Ted is committing a logical fallacy. Ted: Since Edwin wants to argue from the claim that it is possible that Ted's assertion might not be true, Edwin has committed the fallacy of affirming the consequent.

For reasons that are explained here, Engle is in Dubai to do a story on poverty. “You’ve got an interesting story for your next book - a whole country where nearly 25 percent of its people live in absolute poverty…” Engel was reminded of his own experience living in poverty and how some countries are not as developed as others when he attended a dinner with his friend, the British ambassador. One of the ambassadors’ friends said that while Dubai’s booming, Britain is actually doing better than the rest of the world because it has no poverty at all. “I don’t think I’m going to write [that], the UK is not actually the fifth happiest place in the World, by far,” Engel jokingly explained to his friend. “The whole room was staring at me.” “You look like a million dollars,” the ambassador replied. “You could be in Saudi Arabia.” With that, Engel decided to start a web series called Dukestan — a city for the one-fifth of the world. But to describe someone's being a pacifist as "someone who hates war", or a pacifist as "someone who believes war is morally good" is inaccurate. The terms are used to characterize attitudes. Some people may believe that war is a good thing; they may even believe that war is morally right. However, they may have strong moral, religious or personal objections to it and will, consequently, oppose it even if there is an unquestioned necessity for it to defend oneself against an invading force, etc. On this view, these arguments are not persuasive and, to a significant extent, the justification for, say, a war, is not what the non-pacifist thinks, say, that the opponents of the war are saying; but, rather it's what the pacifist's opponent actually believes. The pacifist may believe that the war will not be necessary or that, even if it is necessary, it is wrong; they may believe that a peaceful solution is not possible; they may have a different interpretation of the evidence; or they may be an advocate of peace in the abstract and feel that war is wrong. In this sense pacifism is not the opposite of militarism, it is the opposite of a militaristic mentality. According to a similar argument by William Deresiewicz, pacifism is the "right response to the problem at hand, even if the problem is insoluble; regardless of whose ox is gored; regardless of who dies; regardless of what happens to us. A pacifist is not always a happy person: She is always a faithful person"

sentence: In 2011, Christian broadcaster, Harold Camping, (once again) predicted the end of the world via Jesus, and managed to get many Christians to join his alarmist campaign.  During this time, and especially after the Armageddon date had passed,  many Christian groups publicly declared that Camping is not a “true Christian”.  On a personal note, I think Camping was and is as much of a Christian as any other self-proclaimed Christian and religious/political/ethical beliefs aside, I give him credit for having the cojones to make a falsifiable claim about his religious beliefs.Example #2:
sentence+prompt: In 2011, Christian broadcaster, Harold Camping, (once again) predicted the end of the world via Jesus, and managed to get many Christians to join his alarmist campaign. During this time, and especially after the Armageddon date had passed, many Christian groups publicly declared that Camping is not a “true Christian”. On a personal note, I think Camping was and is as much of a Christian as any other self-proclaimed Christian and religious/political/ethical beliefs aside, I give him credit for having the cojones to make a falsifiable claim about his religious beliefs.Example #2: A: You can’t prove something exists from mere existence, therefore it doesn’t exist B: Your conclusion is a false one because something just exists and nothing else. This is a common tactic of atheists and skeptics, and the two terms are often interchanged. I will explain what I mean by the term “false one” in the first paragraph, and will then explain how it differs from the atheist/skeptical term in the second. If you are a person who believes in God there are many things in our lives that exist but can’t be proved from mere existence/existence and also things that can’t be proved from our existence/existence/being. An example is the Big Bang, something can be said to have existed from its existence/existence, but can’t be proven from its existence because the things that were at the beginning will remain after the Big Bang and those things may have been unable to be seen, heard or measured. In the example of the Christian broadcaster Camping, I would disagree that he is a Christian and that he is/was a “false Christian” because he makes a falsifiable claim about his (his personal) beliefs(i.e. his religion/what he believes) and that claim is that he would use mathematical calculations and historical facts in an attempt to predict where in time, i.e. years, the world will end. On the surface, this means he doesn’t believe that the world will end and he is therefore not a "false Christian" because he is saying something about God’s existence. This is actually not very far off from what many Christians believe (see for example the above example #2 and below). The difference between the “false Christian” and atheists/skeptics lies in the following three points: The Christians and “false Christians” make the claim that things exist independently of their being. This means that they do not believe in God and that if God exists everything that exists is dependent upon God Atheists are just saying that the claim is wrong due to logical fallacy and historical/evolutionary/mathematical facts. There are other arguments as to why the people from the example #1 of the Christian broadcaster are not “false Christians”, and I will not deal with them here. Example #1 is interesting because it’s quite common to have the situation when two or more people say something independently of each other and then one person denies that their claim is true, and the other person says “ok, that’s why you’re wrong” and moves onto another topic with “yeah, well we’re both wrong,”. However,

sentence:
Ted: Biological evolution is both a theory and a fact.
Edwin: That is ridiculous!  How can you possibly be absolutely certain that we evolved from pond scum!
Ted: Actually, that is a gross misrepresentation of my assertion.  I never claimed we evolved from pond scum.  Unlike math and logic, science is based on empirical evidence and, therefore, a scientific fact is something that is confirmed to such a degree that it would be perverse to withhold provisional consent.  The empirical evidence for the fact that biological evolution does occur falls into this category.
sentence+prompt: Ted: Biological evolution is both a theory and a fact. Edwin: That is ridiculous! How can you possibly be absolutely certain that we evolved from pond scum! Ted: Actually, that is a gross misrepresentation of my assertion. I never claimed we evolved from pond scum. Unlike math and logic, science is based on empirical evidence and, therefore, a scientific fact is something that is confirmed to such a degree that it would be perverse to withhold provisional consent. The empirical evidence for the fact that biological evolution does occur falls into this category. Edwin: Are you saying that the universe started as a massive lump of pond scum, that it somehow managed to pull itself together into complex life, that it somehow formed stars, that it somehow got itself to point where we could observe it, and that eventually our species managed to come along and get to observe it. This is incredible! The only way it makes any sort of sense is if you imagine a deity with the mental powers of an amnesiac who somehow created the whole universe from scratch without having any idea that he'd be doing it. If you want to have a religion, fine, but I don't want to have anything to do with your god.

sentence:
Ted: Biological evolution is both a theory and a fact.

Edwin: That is ridiculous!  How can you possibly be absolutely certain that we evolved from pond scum!

Ted: Actually, that is a gross misrepresentation of my assertion.  I never claimed we evolved from pond scum.  Unlike math and logic, science is based on empirical evidence and, therefore, a scientific fact is something that is confirmed to such a degree that it would be perverse to withhold provisional consent.  The empirical evidence for the fact that biological evolution does occur falls into this category.
sentence+prompt: Ted: Biological evolution is both a theory and a fact. Edwin: That is ridiculous! How can you possibly be absolutely certain that we evolved from pond scum! Ted: Actually, that is a gross misrepresentation of my assertion. I never claimed we evolved from pond scum. Unlike math and logic, science is based on empirical evidence and, therefore, a scientific fact is something that is confirmed to such a degree that it would be perverse to withhold provisional consent. The empirical evidence for the fact that biological evolution does occur falls into this category. However, you are correct when you say that I said \’our ancestors were evolved from pond scum.\’ Evolution, by definition, is a long-term process, and pond scum would be a very short-term manifestation of it. It is more accurate to say that we evolved from some other kind of organism, which was eventually digested by pond scum. Anyway, the point of the above example is that the word \'claim\’ should rarely be used. <|endoftext|

sentence:
Becky: I think capital punishment is a necessary component of our justice system and should remain legal.
Alex: So you are saying that murder should be legal and it is okay for us to go around killing people just because we think they deserve it? That isn't right.

Of what fallacy is Alex guilty?
sentence+prompt: Becky: I think capital punishment is a necessary component of our justice system and should remain legal. Alex: So you are saying that murder should be legal and it is okay for us to go around killing people just because we think they deserve it? That isn't right. Of what fallacy is Alex guilty? I'm sure Becky made up or misheard the sentence. Also, how is Alex guilty? A: The fallacy in sentence 14 is called Affirming the Consequent. You state that someone thinks a certain way, so they must be wrong about that, even though you have not proved the person is wrong. A: Sentence 1: "She should not be voted president because she... There's a confusion with the verb used: the action should is verb, but 'because' is a conjunction. The conjunction 'because' means that one argument leads to another, the logical fallacy called Affirming the Consequent is committed when one argument is made and another is used only to prove it. This is particularly damaging for a student as it makes the 'attacker' look foolish. <|endoftext|

sentence:
I know the Professor said that the Bridges of Madison County was smarmy trash and lacked any artistic worth. But I still think he's wrong. After all, it was on the best-seller list for over 100 weeks.

Identify the logical fallacy commited in this argument.
sentence+prompt: I know the Professor said that the Bridges of Madison County was smarmy trash and lacked any artistic worth. But I still think he's wrong. After all, it was on the best-seller list for over 100 weeks. Identify the logical fallacy commited in this argument. I thought that it was a claim by the author, but it should have been an attack, since the author attacked him for reading a book which he thought to be trash. A: Your argument is flawed because the only premise used in your argument is The Professor said that the the best-seller list and the book are correlated, therefore the book is on the list because it's a best-seller. I don't feel it's justified to use this as a premise in your argument, but you have an argument from authority fallacy, so I will deal with this first and move on from there to the book as the premise for your argument. This fallacy states that one cannot argue from a third-person perspective where a claim is made by someone who is unknown or in some other way is not considered to be an authority or trustworthy. Your argument, therefore, is flawed because: The 'author' of the book is not known to be authoritative or trustworthy. This is the best-seller list in your sentence. However, you are using it as a premise to conclude that the author of the book must be a best-seller, an illogical fallacy due to the premise being completely unrelated. <|endoftext|

So, here we have a sentence, in which either the person is a fan of Beyoncé or is a fan of the New England Patriots. However, we're not talking about "favouring" music by either band or team. It sounds like the speaker is trying to make a distinction between the two sentences. The first sentence states that if the university shuts down the library then the author will be in trouble. The second sentence basically says that if the university doesn't raise the tuition, then the library will suffer. However, this kind of distinction makes no sense, so we don't get the difference we want... So really, this question is asking about whether it is a fallacy that the speaker is being deceptive, so that they can be said to have committed a form of word salad - confusingly using word meanings that don't quite fit together. sentence: The fallacy of equivocation occurs when a key term or phrase in an argument is used in an ambiguous way, with one meaning in one portion of the argument and then another meaning in another portion of the argument.
sentence+prompt: The fallacy of equivocation occurs when a key term or phrase in an argument is used in an ambiguous way, with one meaning in one portion of the argument and then another meaning in another portion of the argument. For instance, the phrase "every time I drive past ___, there is a light on my dashboard." When you first read or hear this phrase, it sounds plausible to say 'every time I drive past ___, there is always a light on my dashboard" but what is really meant is that \”there is a light on ___ whenever I drive by\”. However, since my light is on, that means I must have driven by and passed it. The fallacy of equivocation occurs in this argument because one portion of the argument uses the phrase when it means one thing, without specifying that it is meant to mean something else. Event A: first reading the phrase Event B: second reading the phrase Cause: the phrase was used without specifying that it meant something else.

sentence:
Ted: Biological evolution is both a theory and a fact.

Edwin: That is ridiculous!  How can you possibly be absolutely certain that we evolved from pond scum!

Ted: Actually, that is a gross misrepresentation of my assertion.  I never claimed we evolved from pond scum.  Unlike math and logic, science is based on empirical evidence and, therefore, a scientific fact is something that is confirmed to such a degree that it would be perverse to withhold provisional consent.  The empirical evidence for the fact that biological evolution does occur falls into this category.

sentence+prompt: In an example used by Sigmund Freud in The Interpretation of Dreams, a man accused by his neighbor of having returned a kettle in a damaged condition offered three arguments: That he had returned the kettle undamaged; That it was already damaged when he borrowed it; That he had never borrowed it in the first place. In response, Freud says, "Of the three explanations, the first two are logically correct, while the third is a fallacy in that I did not understand that one of the assumptions underlying the proof was the fact that I did not yet know for certain whether that kettle had been returned. Had I known it to be the case, I would surely have admitted my guilt." See also Fallacy of argument from authority Logical fallacy List of fallacies Tactic References Further reading Fallacies: A Study in Critical Reasoning, by T. L. Kocurek How to think logically about your beliefs, by R. J. Sternberg Logic for Law Students, by M. DeMoura Fallacies and Arguments, by J. G. Lipman Fallacies, By B. Consider the following exchange:

Solution 1: Distortion Of what fallacy is the claim guilty? Solution 2: Invalid Conclusion And with that, I think I've solved the fallacy of the "unintentional distortion" question. So now I need to do that one for the rest. Please post your answers for the rest :) A: The most general case is that you are a candidate for class president in [N] class [M] students and your campaign slogan is "Give up in the face of the enemy". Two students enter the hallway complaining that you have a "unintentional distortion" because of your slogan: Student A: We don't have the right to give up in the face of the enemy. Give up to who? How can you possibly believe that? Student B: I guess you want me to give up too. I can't do that. I'm going to keep fighting. The student isn't giving up but is actually saying that we should give up to who? But the claim that you take the statement to be literally true is wrong. Your student isn't giving up but is actually saying that we should give up to who?. For example, consider: Student A: I have a right to be proud of my country. sentence: In the debate at Harvard, one of the Harvard team’s debaters rebutted Samantha Booke’s argument that Henry David Thoreau, a Harvard graduate, proposed civil disobedience as a means to protest unjust laws. The Harvard debater rebutted her by saying, “Thoreau could never know that Adolph Hitler would agree with him.” A BETTER rebuttal would have been to…
sentence+prompt: In the debate at Harvard, one of the Harvard team’s debaters rebutted Samantha Booke’s argument that Henry David Thoreau, a Harvard graduate, proposed civil disobedience as a means to protest unjust laws. The Harvard debater rebutted her by saying, “Thoreau could never know that Adolph Hitler would agree with him.” A BETTER rebuttal would have been to… A. Respond to Samantha’s argument by responding with a well-reasoned, carefully articulated argument and cite evidence to support your position. B. Use evidence from history to refute her position. C. Give a logical argument as to why Hitler would also agree with Henry in the first place. D. Write a short paragraph of 100 to 200 words stating the best response to Sam’s statement and then state your argument in support. The correct answer is A. A: I don't know how you get the idea that you're not looking for an argument, when you ask how to rebut using evidence. That's not the definition of that word. "evidence" (when I read it as a noun) means "a means of proof" or "proof", but it's not a word which should have an argument as it's part of the verb argument. But an argument and the thing you are rebutting are two different things. If you give a "well-reasoned, carefully articulated argument" as you've listed in (B), we don't need to see any evidence for that; someone has to give us both the argument and the evidence, and a well reasoned, carefully articulated argument is an argument. And by the way, the word "evidence" (as a verb) does support using evidence to rebut. <|endoftext|

sentence:
Consider the following exchange:
Lindsey: I think capital punishment is a necessary component of our justice system and should remain legal.
Kayla: So you are saying that murder should be legal and it is okay for us to go around killing people just because we think they deserve it? That isn't right.
Of what fallacy is Kayla guilty?

Kayla: So you are saying that murder should be legal and it is okay for us to go around killing people just because we think they deserve it? That isn't right. Of what fallacy is Kayla guilty? Assumption of Irrelevant Conclusion Thanks, and good luck! A: If I'm honest, I would guess that your problem here is that you're not thinking in "fallacy" as much as in "logic". There are lots of examples that match the definition of "fallacy" that don't match the logic one. So to be more specific, since your question was: "For those who don’t understand the first sentence, they probably have trouble with Sentence 2. Please help me understand this." I think the fallacy in question is the use of the fallacy of the straw man—when you make a false assertion as a means to refute something. The classic case of the straw man is when you hear someone say, "No one believes in creationism." and you reply, "Some people don't believe in evolution." This is a fallacy because evolution is not being questioned. Sentence 2, from the text is clearly a fallacious inference. This is because of the nature of the two claims involved. If your claim is "some people say X" and another claim is "no one says Y", and from this you conclude that X is wrong, then you have fallen into Straw Man: Sentence 2: Students tell Ms. Higgins her hair color looks different on her. Ms. Higgins can't believe her students called ugly and horrendous to look at. This is not true for the following reason: The statement that "Students said Ms. Higgins hair looks different on her" is just false, therefore it's a straw man

sentence:
Joe and Sam are at the race track betting on horses. Joe: "You see that horse over there? He lost his last four races. I'm going to bet on him."
Sam: "Why? I think he will probably lose."
Joe: "No way, Sam. I looked up the horse's stats and he has won half his races in the past two years. Since he has lost three of his last four races, he'll have to win this race. So I'm betting the farm on him."
Sam: "Are you sure?"
Joe: "Of course I'm sure. That pony is due, man...he's due!"
